content.description: The start is tough, trust the painful jams until you get your feet, feel free to utilize the flake as well. Once you get past the start it's a sketchy fist crack to the ledge with good foot options.
content.location: South side of Z-Loft directly left of a chimney, 15 feet right of Crackin' Baskin. Obvious crack running up to a ledge.

content.description: Roof crack start with solid feet, traverse out and up the obvious line, solid hands and feet.
content.location: Right side of the courtyard to the left of Welcome Mat, obvious diagonal crack.

content.description: Fun problem with an overhanging start, pulling over the edge is possible and a good intro to high-balling.
Fight your way up the short offwidth crack to the large ledge.
content.location: South side of Z-Loft, same wall as Crackin' Baskin, a few feet inside the chimney. Can be used as a downclimb from Whisker Fister, they share a top out ledge.

content.description: Start climbing up the obvious crack on the right side of the cave, once you get about 6 ft up you can lay back into the back of the chimney to pass the thin section, you can just about lay back at any time to rest or place gear, the crack takes passive and active pro really well until the last ten feet or so where it turns into this horrible pebbly stuff. At that point make the short run out until you reach the large boulder that serves as the roof of the "cave", stick one last cam in the vertical crack and traverse right using this crack and exit out the top. Gritty route that's a great mix of crack and chimney climbing. Pro Tip: Bring a headlamp.
content.location: The chimney "cave" directly right of the Courtyard Wall, inside you'll see a nice little crack running up the right side.

content.description: An awkward start on some weathered conglom. A couple good jugs bring you to a rest on a sloping face, followed by a fun finger/hand crack to the top-out.
content.protection: TR from trees at the top.
content.location: Located at the northern end of the area.

content.description: Follow the vertical crack up to where it intersects with the horizontal crack, go right on the horizontal and follow it as it curves up vertical again (this is probably the crux). Once vertical again follow it up to a nice ledge that you can rest on before following the hand crack up to top out.
content.protection: Cams, can be tricky to get them set just right so be aware.
content.location: From the courtyard follow the cliff left, just past Beaver face, you'll see the obvious "P" shaped line on a face just left of a chimney.

content.description: If you can avoid the sections of moss, you'll find some fun climbs on this large boulder. There actually are trees at the top for TR anchors, but the only way to get up is to lead a climb or solo it.
content.protection: TR, crashpad, or marginal pro placements.
content.location: Northern most end of the area.

content.description: Juggy overhanging start up to the arete, go right until the obvious deep horizontal cut ends and move up to a small horn you can use to top out. Crux is the last sequence before the horn.
content.protection: Crash pad on the boulder to protect the start, the corner of the horizontal crack will take cams, possibly sling a small hole in the rock to protect the crux move. Anchor off a selection of trees at the top.
content.location: Southern side, opposite side of a small courtyard from a chimney with what looks to be a precariously perched boulder.

content.description: Start towards the bottom on the pinch and use the solid feet to move up to the obvious large flake. Last few moves are tricky right before the top out so make sure you have a spotter. You can get down by sliding down the "ramp" to your left after the top out.
content.location: Go left at the courtyard, large boulders left of the main cliff face you will see one with a huge hollow flake leaning in to the side of it. Opposite side of the giant flake you will see a vertical wall with a tree growing into a crack in the middle, to the left of the tree crack is the problem.

content.description: The first couple moves are really painful hand jams in flaring conglomerate, the rock smooths out before you reach the crux, moving out and up the large rounded flake. It finishes off with some juggy overhanging moves as the crack dies out.
content.protection: A couple cams in the middle and a sling through a hole after the crack dies out.
content.location: South side, around the corner from Slippin' Jimmy.

content.description: This wall has 2 cracks that have been climbed so far. Both kinda die out just a few feet before the top-out. Fun climbs though, a good way to get your hands used to the conglom that dominates the area.
content.location: Located in the courtyard closest to the parking area, the Welcome Mat boulder is just adjacent.

content.description: A very fun boulder with many features to choose from. Top roping is a possibility, but the overhang is so severe that it's not very practical unless you stay off to the sides. Be prepared to find some loose rock and choss.
A balancey route. Start on the arete on the left and move up and to the right to top out. Use the available pockets.
content.location: From the beginning of Z-loft where the campfire is, head to the left of the big wall and follow the path past a few chimneys until you come to a boulder face next to a blank white slab with some graffiti.

content.description: This large cave contains a couple routes. All are right around the 5.9 range and offer surprisingly good pro placements, and a single fixed pin to rapp off of.
content.protection: No bolts yet, a single fixed pin to rapp from.

content.description: A LOT of work to be done in this area. With the attention of a few dedicated climbers, this area could be a very impressive climbing destination. A 1/4 mile long wall ranging from 75 to 100 feet of climbable rock. Top roping is a good idea for anyone coming here for the first time, as there is still a lot of loose rock and even moss that may jeopardize your pro placements. When setting up a TR, stay on trails or clearly solid areas. Numerous crevasses are hidden by fallen foliage and years of small brush growth. Just be careful, and be sure to record your first ascents!
